Detailed Description

A Fragment is a piece of an application's user interface or behavior that can be placed in an Page.

Interaction with fragments is done through FragmentManager, which can be obtained via Page::getFragmentManager() and Fragment::getFragmentManager().

The Fragment class can be used many ways to achieve a wide variety of results. It is core, it represents a particular operation or interface that is running within a larger Page. A Fragment is closely tied to the Page it is in, and can not be used apart from one. Though Fragment defines its own lifecycle, that lifecycle is dependent on its page: if the page is stopped, no fragments inside of it can be started; when the page is destroyed, all fragments will be destroyed.

All subclasses of Fragment must include a public empty constructor. The framework will often re-instantiate a fragment class when needed, in particular during state restore, and needs to be able to find this constructor to instantiate it. If the empty constructor is not available, a runtime exception will occur in some cases during state restore.

Topics covered here:

  1. Lifecycle
  2. Back Stack

Lifecycle

Though a Fragment's lifecycle is tied to its owning page, it has its own wrinkle on the standard page lifecycle. It includes basic page lifecycle methods such as onResume, but also important are methods related to interactions with the page and UI generation.

The core series of lifecycle methods that are called to bring a fragment up to resumed state (interacting with the user) are:

  1. onAttach called once the fragment is associated with its Page.
  2. onCreate called to do initial creation of the fragment.
  3. onCreateWidget creates and returns the Widget hierarchy associated with the fragment.
  4. onPageCreated tells the fragment that its page has completed its own Page::onInit.
  5. onStart makes the fragment visible to the user (based on its containing page being started).
  6. onResume makes the fragment interacting with the user (based on its containing page being resumed).

As a fragment is no longer being used, it goes through a reverse series of callbacks:

  1. onPause fragment is no longer interacting with the user either because its page is being paused or a fragment operation is modifying it in the page.
  2. onStop fragment is no longer visible to the user either because its page is being stopped or a fragment operation is modifying it in the page.
  3. onDestroyWidget allows the fragment to clean up resources associated with its Widget.
  4. onDestroy called to do final cleanup of the fragment's state.
  5. onDetach called immediately prior to the fragment no longer being associated with its page.

Back Stack

The transaction in which fragments are modified can be placed on an internal back-stack of the owning page. When the user presses back in the page, any transactions on the back stack are popped off before the page itself is finished.

After each call to this function, a new entry is on the stack, and pressing back will pop it to return the user to whatever previous state the page UI was in.

Definition at line 116 of file Fragment.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

gaia::core::Fragment::Fragment ( )

Default constructor.

Every fragment must have an empty constructor, so it can be instantiated when restoring its page's state. It is strongly recommended that subclasses do not have other constructors with parameters, since these constructors will not be called when the fragment is re-instantiated; instead, arguments can be supplied by the caller with setArguments and later retrieved by the Fragment with getArguments.

Applications should generally not implement a constructor. The first place application code an run where the fragment is ready to be used is in onAttach(Page* page), the point where the fragment is actually associated with its page.

FragmentManager gaia::core::Fragment::getFragmentManager ( )

Return the FragmentManager for interacting with fragments associated with this fragment's page.

Note that this will be non-null slightly before getPage(), during the time from when the fragment is placed in a FragmentTransaction until it is committed and attached to its page.

This is the container widget ID supplied when adding the fragment.

static Fragment* gaia::core::Fragment::instantiate ( Context *  context,
const base::String &  classname,
Persistence *  args 
) [static]

Create a new instance of a Fragment with the given class name.

This is the same as calling its empty constructor.

Parameters:
contextThe calling context being used to instantiate the fragment. This is currently just used to get its ClassLoader.
classnameThe class name of the fragment to instantiate.
argsPersistence of arguments to supply to the fragment, which it can retrieve with getArguments(). May be NULL.
Returns:
Returns a new fragment instance.
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onAttach ( Page *  page) [virtual]

Called when a fragment is first attached to its page.

onCreate(Persistence*) will be called after this.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onConfigurationChanged ( gaia::content::Configuration *const  newConfig) [virtual]
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onCreate ( Persistence *  savedInstanceState) [virtual]

Called to do initial creation of a fragment.

This is called after onAttach(Page*) and before #onCreateView(Persistence).

Note that this can be called while the fragment's page is still in the process of being created. As such, you can not rely on things like the page's content widget hierarchy being initialized at this point. If you want to do work once the page itself is created, see #onPageCreated(Persistence).

Parameters:
savedInstanceStateIf the fragment is being re-created from a previous saved state, this is the state.
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onCreateOptionsMenu ( Menu *  menu) [virtual]

Initialize the contents of the Page's standard options menu.

You should place your menu items in to menu. For this method to be called, you must have first called setHasOptionsMenu. See Page::onCreateOptionsMenu for more information.

Parameters:
menuThe options menu in which you place your items.
See also:
setHasOptionsMenu
onPrepareOptionsMenu
onOptionsItemSelected
virtual Widget* gaia::core::Fragment::onCreateWidget ( LayoutInflater *  inflater,
WidgetController *  container,
Persistence *  savedInstanceState 
) [virtual]

Called to have the fragment instantiate its user interface widget.

This is optional, and non-graphical fragments can return null (which is the default implementation). This will be called between onCreate(Persistence*) and onPageCreated(Persistence*).

If you return a View from here, you will later be called in onDestroyWidget when the widget is being released.

Parameters:
inflaterThe LayoutInflater Object that can be used to inflate any widgets in the fragment,
containerIf non-null, this is the parent widget that the fragment's UI should be attached to. The fragment should not add the widget itself, but this can be used to generate the LayoutParams of the widget.
savedInstanceStateIf non-null, this fragment is being re-constructed from a previous saved state as given here.
Returns:
Return the Widget for the fragment's UI, or NULL.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ListFragment, and gaia::webkit::WebViewFragment.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onDestroy ( ) [virtual]

Called when the fragment is no longer in use.

This is called after onStop() and before onDetach().

Reimplemented in gaia::webkit::WebViewFragment.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onDestroyOptionsMenu ( ) [virtual]

Called when this fragment's option menu items are no longer being included in the overall options menu.

Receiving this call means that the menu needed to be rebuilt, but this fragment's items were not included in the newly built menu (its onCreateOptionsMenu(Menu*) was not called).

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onDestroyWidget ( ) [virtual]

Called when the widget previously created by onCreateWidget has been detached from the fragment.

The next time the fragment needs to be displayed, a new widget will be created. This is called after onStop() and before onDestroy(). It is called regardless of whether onCreateWidget returned a non-null widget. Internally it is called after the widget's state has been saved but before it has been removed from its parent.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ListFragment, and gaia::webkit::WebViewFragment.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onDetach ( ) [virtual]

Called when the fragment is no longer attached to its page.

This is called after onDestroy().

virtual bool gaia::core::Fragment::onOptionsItemSelected ( MenuItem *  item) [virtual]

This hook is called whenever an item in your options menu is selected.

The default implementation simply returns false to have the normal processing happen (calling the item's Runnable or sending a message to its Handler as appropriate). You can use this method for any items for which you would like to do processing without those other facilities.

Derived classes should call through to the base class for it to perform the default menu handling.

Parameters:
itemThe menu item that was selected.
Returns:
bool Return false to allow normal menu processing to proceed, true to consume it here.
See also:
onCreateOptionsMenu
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onOptionsMenuClosed ( Menu *  menu) [virtual]

This hook is called whenever the options menu is being closed (either by the user canceling the menu with the back/menu button, or when an item is selected).

Parameters:
menuThe options menu as last shown or first initialized by onCreateOptionsMenu.
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onPageCreated ( Persistence *  savedInstanceState) [virtual]

Called when the fragment's page has been created and this fragment's widget hierarchy instantiated.

It can be used to do final initialization once these pieces are in place, such as retrieving widgets or restoring state. It is also useful for fragments that use #setRetainInstance(bool) to retain their instance, as this callback tells the fragment when it is fully associated with the new page instance. This is called after onCreateWidget and before onStart().

Parameters:
savedInstanceStateIf the fragment is being re-created from a previous saved state, this is the state.
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onPageResult ( int32_t  requestCode,
int32_t  resultCode,
Demand *  data 
) [virtual]

Receive the result from a previous call to startPageForResult(Demand*, int32_t).

This follows the related Page API as described there in Page::onPageResult(int32_t, int32_t, Demand*).

Parameters:
requestCodeThe integer request code originally supplied to startPageForResult(), allowing you to identify who this result came from.
resultCodeThe integer result code returned by the child Page through its setResult().
dataAn Demand, which can return result data to the caller (various data can be attached to Intent "extras").
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onPause ( ) [virtual]

Called when the Fragment is no longer resumed.

This is generally tied to Page::onPause of the containing Page's lifecycle.

Reimplemented in gaia::webkit::WebViewFragment.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onPrepareOptionsMenu ( Menu *  menu) [virtual]

Prepare the Screen's standard options menu to be displayed.

This is called right before the menu is shown, every time it is shown. You can use this method to efficiently enable/disable items or otherwise dynamically modify the contents. See Page::onPrepareOptionsMenu for more information.

Parameters:
menuThe options menu as last shown or first initialized by onCreateOptionsMenu.
See also:

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onResume ( ) [virtual]

Called when the fragment is visible to the user and page running.

This is generally tied to Page::onResume() of the containing Page's lifecycle.

Reimplemented in gaia::webkit::WebViewFragment.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onSaveInstanceState ( Persistence *  outState) [virtual]

Called to ask the fragment to save its current dynamic state, so it can later be reconstructed in a new instance of its process is restarted.

If a new instance of the fragment later needs to be created, the data you place in the Persistence here will be available in the Persistence given to onCreate(Persistence*), onCreateWidget(Persistence*), and onPageCreated(Persistence*).

This corresponds to Page::onSaveInstanceState(Persistence*) and most of the discussion there applies here as well. Note however: this method may be called at any time before onDestroy(). There are many situations where a fragment may be mostly torn down (such as when placed on the back stack with no UI showing), but its state will not be saved until its owning page actually needs to save its state.

Parameters:
outStatePersistence in which to place your saved state.
virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onStart ( ) [virtual]

Called when the Fragment is visible to the user.

This is generally tied to Page::onStart() of the containing Page's lifecycle.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onStop ( ) [virtual]

Called when the Fragment is no longer started.

This is generally tied to Page::onStop of the containing Page's lifecycle.

virtual void gaia::core::Fragment::onWidgetCreated ( Widget *  widget,
Persistence *  savedInstanceState 
) [virtual]

Called immediately after onCreateWidget(LayoutInflater*, WidgetController*, Persistence*) has returned, but before any saved state has been restored in to the widget.

This gives subclasses a chance to initialize themselves once they know their widget hierarchy has been completely created. The fragment's widget hierarchy is not however attached to its parent at this point.

Parameters:
widgetThe Widget returned by onCreateWidget(LayoutInflater*, WidgetController*, Persistence*).
savedInstanceStateIf non-null, this fragment is being re-constructed from a previous saved state as given here.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ListFragment.

void gaia::core::Fragment::setArguments ( Persistence *  args)

Supply the construction arguments for this fragment.

This can only be called before the fragment has been attached to its page; that is, you should call it immediately after constructing the fragment. The arguments supplied here will be retained across fragment destroy and creation.

void gaia::core::Fragment::setHasOptionsMenu ( bool  has)

Report that this fragment would like to participate in populating the options menu by receiving a call to #onCreateOptionsMenu(Menu*, MenuInflater*) and related methods.

void gaia::core::Fragment::setTargetFragment ( Fragment *  fragment,
int32_t  requestCode 
)

Optional target for this fragment.

This may be used, for example, if this fragment is being started by another, and when done wants to give a result back to the first. The target set here is retained across instances via FragmentManager::putFragment().

Parameters:
fragmentThe fragment that is the target of this one.
requestCodeOptional request code, for convenience if you are going to call back with onPageResult(int32_t, int32_t, Demand*).
void gaia::core::Fragment::startPage ( Demand *  demand)

Call Page::startPage(Demand*) on the fragment's containing Page.

void gaia::core::Fragment::startPageForResult ( Demand *  demand,
int32_t  requestCode 
)

Call Page::startPageForResult(Demand*, int) on the fragment's containing Page.
